content.text: Science seeks to discover **laws of nature** - universal generalizations that hold across all times and places. But how do we get from observing particular cases to believing universal laws?

content.definition: A statement claiming that ALL members of a class have some property. Example: 'All metals expand when heated.' Scientific laws are universal generalizations.

content.title: From Observations to Law
premises: This piece of copper expanded when heated.
That piece of iron expanded when heated.
Every metal we've tested expanded when heated.
content.conclusion: Therefore, ALL metals expand when heated.
content.note: This is inductive: we've only observed some metals, but conclude about all metals.

content.definition: Evidence that supports a hypothesis or law. Each positive instance (observing a metal that expands) confirms the generalization to some degree.

symbols.name: Just Happens to Be True
symbols.example: All coins in my pocket are quarters

symbols.name: Would-Be Truths
symbols.example: If this WERE copper, it WOULD conduct

content.text: The difference between laws and accidents is important. 'All ravens are black' (if true) is a law - it supports 'If this were a raven, it would be black.' But 'All coins in my pocket are quarters' doesn't support 'If this coin were in my pocket, it would be a quarter.'

content.question: What distinguishes a law of nature from an accidental generalization?
content.explanation: Laws of nature support counterfactual reasoning - they tell us what WOULD happen in hypothetical cases. 'All copper conducts' supports 'If this were copper, it would conduct.' Accidental generalizations like 'All my pets are cats' don't support 'If this were my pet, it would be a cat.'
